body: Reverting https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/29155 on the client fixes the issue. For some reason, setting `RECV_INITIAL_METADATA` changes the error message?

When deadline exceed, [CallError raised](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/v1.55.0/src/ruby/ext/grpc/rb_call.c#L864), then [remote_read](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/v1.55.0/src/ruby/lib/grpc/generic/active_call.rb#L259) aborted without setting `@metadata_received = true`.
With https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/33283, [receive_and_check_status](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/v1.55.0/src/ruby/lib/grpc/generic/active_call.rb#L168) finds out  `@metadata_received` is false, so RECV_INITIAL_METADATA is sent again and caused the `grpc_call_start_batch failed with outstanding read or write present (code=8)` error.

The complexity here is that there is not enough information propagated to active_call.rb that whether `RECV_INITIAL_METADATA` was sent or not when there was a CallError.

However send `RECV_STATUS_ON_CLIENT` alone without `RECV_INITIAL_METADATA` (although against grpc protocol) indeed can correctly get the deadline exceed error.

As a result I think reverting https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/29155 might be a good idea, and it appeared didn't solve the mentioned test failure in the PR, which was also a deadline exceed error I think may actually caused by test running slow.

CC: @apolcyn

issue.title: [ruby] Revert "make sure to always receive initial metadata in ruby (#29155)"

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
#29155  caused the Ruby client to return `grpc_call_start_batch failed with outstanding read or write present (code=8)` instead of `DeadlineExceeded`.

This reverts commit fe1345650439ebdec5aa7fc882f10168cf60e696.

Closes #33283




<!--

If you know who should review your pull request, please assign it to that
person, otherwise the pull request would get assigned randomly.

If your pull request is for a specific language, please add the appropriate
lang label.

-->

body: Thanks, I've submitted a revert in https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/33408.

@apolcyn @ctiller This issue actually caused a significant regression in production because we handle `DeadlineExceeded` and other `StandardError` types gracefully, but `GRPC::Core::CallError` does NOT inherit from `StandardError`: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/14c63c70afdb52d94f6cf8c2a163f205156d4ba1/src/ruby/ext/grpc/rb_call.c#L989-L991

I believe the revert in https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/33408 solves this issue, so I would appreciate a quick review. Thanks!

issue.title: [ruby] Make `GRPC::DeadlineExceeded` report properly

labels.name: release notes: no
labels.description: Indicates if PR should not be in release notes

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
In grpc v1.46.2 and later versions, #29155 caused the Ruby client to return `GRPC::Core::CallError`, a non-standard error, with a message: `grpc_call_start_batch failed with outstanding read or write present (code=8)`. However, the actual error should have been `GRPC::DeadlineExceeded`. This occurred because when `GRPC::DeadlineExceeded` is raised, the `@metadata_received` flag doesn't get flipped. When `receive_and_check_status` runs to determine
the error, the `RECV_INITIAL_METADATA` is erroneously sent again.

To avoid this, flip the flag in an `ensure` block whenever the `RECV_INITIAL_METADATA` op is set.

Closes #33283
